title: Psalms Chapter 77 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 77 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 77 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 77.

questions.question: Who is the Psalm of Psalms 77 dedicated to?
questions.correctAnswer: Asaph
questions.explanation: The Psalm is specifically noted as a Psalm of Asaph in Psalms 77:1.

questions.question: What did the Psalmist do when in trouble according to Psalms 77:2?
questions.correctAnswer: Sought the Lord
questions.explanation: The Psalmist states he sought the Lord in the day of trouble as per Psalms 77:2.

questions.question: What effect did remembering God have on the Psalmist in Psalms 77:3?
questions.correctAnswer: He was troubled
questions.explanation: The Psalmist says he remembered God and was troubled in Psalms 77:3.

questions.question: What kept the Psalmist's eyes awake according to Psalms 77:4?
questions.correctAnswer: Trouble
questions.explanation: The verse says 'Thou holdest mine eyes waking: I am so troubled that I cannot speak.' (Psalms 77:4).

questions.question: What did the Psalmist consider in Psalms 77:5?
questions.correctAnswer: The days of old
questions.explanation: The Psalmist says he considered the days of old and years of ancient times in Psalms 77:5.

questions.question: According to Psalms 77:7, what question does the Psalmist ask about the Lord?
options: Will the Lord cast off forever?
Will the Lord bless the fields?
Will the Lord heal the sick?
Will the Lord forget His people?
questions.correctAnswer: Will the Lord cast off forever?
questions.explanation: The Psalmist asks if the Lord will cast off forever and be favourable no more in Psalms 77:7.

questions.question: What does the Psalmist say about God's mercy in Psalms 77:8?
options: Is His mercy clean gone forever?
Is His mercy new every morning?
questions.correctAnswer: Is His mercy clean gone forever?
questions.explanation: The Psalmist questions if God's mercy is completely gone forever in Psalms 77:8.

questions.question: What does the Psalmist call his condition in Psalms 77:10?
questions.correctAnswer: My infirmity
questions.explanation: The Psalmist refers to his condition as 'my infirmity' in Psalms 77:10.

questions.question: What will the Psalmist remember according to Psalms 77:11?
questions.correctAnswer: The works of the LORD
questions.explanation: The Psalmist says he will remember the works of the LORD and wonders of old in Psalms 77:11.

questions.question: Where does the Psalmist say God's way is found in Psalms 77:13?
questions.correctAnswer: In the sanctuary
questions.explanation: Psalms 77:13 states 'Thy way, O God, is in the sanctuary.'

questions.question: Who did God redeem with His arm according to Psalms 77:15?
options: The sons of Jacob and Joseph
questions.correctAnswer: The sons of Jacob and Joseph
questions.explanation: Psalms 77:15 says God redeemed 'the sons of Jacob and Joseph' with His arm.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 77:16, the waters were afraid when they saw God.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 77:16 states the waters saw God and were afraid.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 77:18 describes the earth as trembling and shaking because of God's voice and lightnings.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The verse describes the earth trembling and shaking due to God's thunder and lightnings (Psalms 77:18).

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 77:20 says God led His people like a flock by the hand of Moses and Aaron.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The Psalm states God led His people like a flock by Moses and Aaron's hand (Psalms 77:20).

questions.question: Complete the verse from Psalms 77:12: 'I will meditate also of all thy ______, and talk of thy doings.'
questions.correctAnswer: work
questions.explanation: Psalms 77:12 says 'I will meditate also of all thy work, and talk of thy doings.'

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 77 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 77 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Psalms 77, what biblical truth would you share about seeking God in times of trouble?
options: Cry out to God with your voice, for He hears your prayers
Try to handle problems alone without prayer
Ignore your troubles and focus only on happy moments
Seek advice only from friends, not God
questions.correctAnswer: Cry out to God with your voice, for He hears your prayers
questions.explanation: Psalms 77:1 teaches us to cry out to God with our voice in times of trouble, trusting that He gives ear to us. Verses 2 and 3 also show the psalmist seeking the Lord in distress and remembering God's past faithfulness.

questions.question: How does Psalms 77 instruct believers to handle overwhelming sorrow and lack of comfort?
options: Refuse to be comforted but remember God's works and wonders
Give up hope and stop praying
questions.correctAnswer: Refuse to be comforted but remember God's works and wonders
questions.explanation: In Psalms 77:2-3, the psalmist's soul refuses to be comforted, yet in verses 10-12 he chooses to remember God's mighty acts and meditate on His works. This teaches perseverance in faith during sorrow.

questions.question: In Psalms 77, what practice does the psalmist use to strengthen faith when doubting God's mercy?
options: Remembering the years of the right hand of the Most High
Ignoring doubts and pretending everything is fine
questions.correctAnswer: Remembering the years of the right hand of the Most High
questions.explanation: Verse 10 shows the psalmist recognizing his weakness but choosing to remember God's mighty hand in the past. Verses 11-12 further emphasize recalling and meditating on God’s works as a way to restore faith.

questions.question: What does Psalms 77 teach about the importance of meditation and reflection in spiritual life?
options: Meditate on all God's work and talk of His doings
questions.correctAnswer: Meditate on all God's work and talk of His doings
questions.explanation: Verse 12 encourages meditating on God's works and speaking of His deeds, indicating the value of reflection and testimony in strengthening faith and obedience.

questions.question: How can Psalms 77 inspire believers to trust God's power and protection?
options: By remembering that God has declared His strength and done wonders among the people
By doubting God's ability to help
By relying only on human strength
questions.correctAnswer: By remembering that God has declared His strength and done wonders among the people
questions.explanation: Verses 14 and 15 speak of God’s wonders and His redeeming power through His arm, which encourages trust in His protection and strength in daily life.

questions.question: A believer feels abandoned by God and wonders if His mercy has failed. Based on Psalms 77, what would you counsel?
options: God’s mercy has not failed; remember His promises and past gracious acts
God no longer cares, so give up faith
Look for mercy only from people
questions.correctAnswer: God’s mercy has not failed; remember His promises and past gracious acts
questions.explanation: Verses 7-9 express the psalmist’s doubts but verse 10-11 affirm remembering God's mercy and works. This encourages perseverance and trust despite feelings of abandonment.

questions.question: How does Psalms 77 illustrate God’s guidance and leadership in difficult times?
options: God leads His people like a flock by the hand of Moses and Aaron
God leaves people to wander without direction
People must find their own way without God
Leadership is only human and not divine
questions.correctAnswer: God leads His people like a flock by the hand of Moses and Aaron
questions.explanation: Verse 20 describes God’s guidance through Moses and Aaron, illustrating His caring leadership and direction especially during trials.

questions.question: What biblical virtue does the psalmist model when he calls to remembrance the days of old and ancient times?
options: Faith and trust in God's enduring faithfulness
questions.correctAnswer: Faith and trust in God's enduring faithfulness
questions.explanation: Verse 5 highlights remembering God's past faithfulness as a foundation for trust, a virtue essential for perseverance and hope in Christian life.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 77, the psalmist’s soul refused to be comforted during his night of trouble.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 77:2 states that the psalmist’s soul refused to be comforted during his distress, illustrating honest lament and the struggle in faith during trials.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 77 teaches that God’s ways are hidden and unknown even to His people.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verse 19 says God’s way is in the sea and His path in the great waters, but His footsteps are not known. This expresses God’s mysterious ways rather than being completely unknown, encouraging trust despite mystery.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Psalms 77 says, 'Thy way, O God, is in the _______: who is so great a God as our God?'
questions.correctAnswer: sanctuary
questions.explanation: Verse 13 declares 'Thy way, O God, is in the sanctuary,' affirming God's holiness and greatness, encouraging believers to revere Him and trust His guidance.

questions.question: What does the psalmist reveal about prayer and personal devotion in the night of trouble?
options: He calls to remembrance his song and communes with his own heart
He refuses to pray or think about God
He ignores his feelings and stays silent
questions.correctAnswer: He calls to remembrance his song and communes with his own heart
questions.explanation: Verse 6 shows the psalmist using night-time prayer and reflection as spiritual disciplines to seek God’s presence and comfort in trouble.

questions.question: How does Psalms 77 encourage believers to testify about God’s deeds?
options: By talking of all His works and meditating on His doings
By hiding their faith to avoid conflict
By only thinking silently without sharing
questions.correctAnswer: By talking of all His works and meditating on His doings
questions.explanation: Verse 12 instructs believers to meditate on God's work and openly talk about His deeds, promoting evangelism and encouraging fellowship grounded in testimony.

questions.question: According to Psalms 77, how should believers respond when overwhelmed and unable to speak about their troubles?
options: Recognize God’s presence even in silence and maintain trust
questions.correctAnswer: Recognize God’s presence even in silence and maintain trust
questions.explanation: Verse 4 shows the psalmist’s eyes held awake by trouble and inability to speak, but the surrounding verses encourage remembering God and trusting Him even in silent suffering.

questions.question: What lesson about God's power is conveyed by the imagery of waters, clouds, thunder, and lightnings in Psalms 77?
options: God displays His strength through natural wonders that cause awe and fear
Nature is unrelated to God's character
Such events are random and meaningless
questions.correctAnswer: God displays His strength through natural wonders that cause awe and fear
questions.explanation: Verses 16-18 describe God’s power shown in waters, thunder, and lightning, symbolizing His awesome strength and sovereignty, encouraging reverence and faith.

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 77 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 77.

questions.question: In Psalms 77, the psalmist cries out to God with his voice. What is the significance of this repeated emphasis on vocal prayer in the context of ancient Israelite worship?
options: It underscores the urgency and intensity of the psalmist’s distress
It highlights the communal nature of worship in the temple
It reflects a ritual chant used during the Day of Atonement
It indicates a formal legal accusation against God
questions.correctAnswer: It underscores the urgency and intensity of the psalmist’s distress
questions.explanation: Psalms 77:1 emphasizes crying unto God with voice, illustrating the psalmist’s desperate plea during trouble, reflecting personal anguish rather than communal liturgy.

questions.question: The question in Psalms 77:7, "Will the Lord cast off forever? and will he be favorable no more?" reflects which common theological tension in the Hebrew Bible?
options: The tension between divine justice and mercy
The tension between God’s covenant faithfulness and human suffering
The tension between idolatry and monotheism
The tension between priestly and prophetic authority
questions.correctAnswer: The tension between God’s covenant faithfulness and human suffering
questions.explanation: This verse reveals the psalmist wrestling with apparent divine abandonment, a theme common in the Hebrew Bible where covenant promises are questioned amidst suffering.

questions.question: What literary device is prominently used in Psalms 77:11-12 where the psalmist declares, "I will remember the works of the LORD... I will meditate also of all thy work,"?
options: Chiasm highlighting the centrality of God's works
Allegory about the journey of the soul
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism emphasizing remembrance and meditation
questions.explanation: Verses 11-12 use synonymous parallelism, a common Hebrew poetic structure, to stress the importance of recalling and reflecting on God's deeds.

questions.question: In Psalms 77:13, "Thy way, O God, is in the sanctuary," what does the term 'sanctuary' signify in the ancient Israelite context?
options: The divine presence dwelling among the people
A physical fortress protecting the city
A natural mountain where sacrifices were offered
questions.correctAnswer: The divine presence dwelling among the people
questions.explanation: The sanctuary refers to the holy place where God’s presence dwells, central to Israelite worship and theology, as emphasized in this verse.

questions.question: The phrase "Thou hast with thine arm redeemed thy people, the sons of Jacob and Joseph" (Psalms 77:15) is an example of what biblical theme?
questions.correctAnswer: Divine deliverance and covenant faithfulness
questions.explanation: The verse highlights God’s redemptive power, recalling the Exodus motif where God’s arm signifies strength and salvation for Israel.

questions.question: Psalms 77:16-18 describe natural phenomena such as waters, clouds, thunder, and lightning. What is the primary theological purpose of these images?
options: To depict God’s sovereign power over creation
To describe weather patterns in Canaan
To symbolize the chaos of the sea gods
questions.correctAnswer: To depict God’s sovereign power over creation
questions.explanation: The imagery of natural forces portrays God's mighty acts, reinforcing His control over chaos and affirming His greatness.

questions.question: The rhetorical question in Psalms 77:9, "Hath God forgotten to be gracious? Hath he in anger shut up his tender mercies?" employs what literary technique?
questions.correctAnswer: Anthropopathism attributing emotions to God
questions.explanation: The psalmist ascribes human emotions like anger and forgetfulness to God to express his distress, a common biblical literary device.

questions.question: True or False: The psalmist in Psalms 77 ultimately finds reassurance by recalling God's past wonders and acts of deliverance.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 77:11-15 show the psalmist’s shift from despair to remembrance of God’s mighty works, providing comfort and hope.

questions.question: In Psalms 77:19, "Thy way is in the sea, and thy path in the great waters," what Old Testament event is alluded to by this imagery?
options: The parting of the Red Sea during the Exodus
The flood in the time of Noah
The crossing of the Jordan River into Canaan
questions.correctAnswer: The parting of the Red Sea during the Exodus
questions.explanation: The phrase recalls God's miraculous leading of Israel through the Red Sea, a foundational deliverance event in Israel’s history.

questions.question: The reference to Moses and Aaron in Psalms 77:20 serves what purpose in the psalmist’s argument?
options: To highlight the divine guidance through appointed leaders
To criticize the priestly leadership of the time
To describe a future messianic figure
questions.correctAnswer: To highlight the divine guidance through appointed leaders
questions.explanation: Mentioning Moses and Aaron evokes God's faithful leadership of Israel through His chosen servants, reinforcing trust in divine providence.

questions.question: What is the significance of the repeated use of the word 'Selah' in Psalms 77?
options: It indicates a pause for reflection or musical interlude
It marks the end of the psalm
It is a call to gather for communal prayer
It signifies a change in speaker
questions.correctAnswer: It indicates a pause for reflection or musical interlude
questions.explanation: ‘Selah’ is a liturgical or musical term inviting the listener or reader to pause and contemplate the preceding words, common in Psalms.

questions.question: How does the psalmist's struggle with God's apparent absence in Psalms 77 relate to the theme of divine hiddenness found elsewhere in the Hebrew Bible?
options: It reflects a common prophetic lament over God's silence
It denies the existence of God
It is unique to Psalms 77 and not found elsewhere
It celebrates God's silence as holy
questions.correctAnswer: It reflects a common prophetic lament over God's silence
questions.explanation: The psalmist’s complaint echoes prophetic motifs (e.g., Habakkuk, Jeremiah) where God's hiddenness causes distress but ultimately calls for faith.

questions.question: The phrase "my soul refused to be comforted" (Psalms 77:2) in Hebrew uses a verb that implies what about the psalmist’s emotional state?
options: A stubborn or resolute refusal to accept consolation
questions.correctAnswer: A stubborn or resolute refusal to accept consolation
questions.explanation: The Hebrew verb conveys a strong, persistent rejection of comfort, indicating deep distress and inner turmoil.

questions.question: In Psalms 77, the psalmist’s meditation on "the days of old" (verse 5) serves what literary and theological function?
options: To establish continuity of God’s faithfulness over time
To promote nostalgia for the monarchy
questions.correctAnswer: To establish continuity of God’s faithfulness over time
questions.explanation: Reflecting on ancient times reassures the psalmist of God’s enduring covenant, encouraging trust despite present troubles.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 77 is attributed to Asaph, who was one of the chief musicians and seers in ancient Israel.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The superscription in Psalms 77:1 attributes the psalm to Asaph, known from other biblical passages as a prominent Levitical musician and prophet.

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 77 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 77 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: How does the psalmist describe his initial approach to God in his distress in Psalms 77?
options: He cried unto God with his voice
He silently meditated without crying out
He sought advice from the elders
He fled from God in fear
questions.correctAnswer: He cried unto God with his voice
questions.explanation: Psalms 77:1 states, 'I cried unto God with my voice, even unto God with my voice; and he gave ear unto me,' showing an active, vocal petition. This aligns with other scriptures such as Psalm 34:17, Jeremiah 33:3, Romans 10:13, and Revelation 6:10 where crying out to God represents earnest prayer in distress.

questions.question: What is the psalmist’s experience of comfort during his night of trouble according to Psalms 77?
options: His soul refused to be comforted
questions.correctAnswer: His soul refused to be comforted
questions.explanation: Psalms 77:2 says, 'my soul refused to be comforted,' indicating deep anguish and lack of consolation. This echoes themes in Job 3:11, Psalm 42:5, Lamentations 3:17, and 2 Corinthians 1:8 where the soul experiences profound distress without immediate relief.

questions.question: What mental struggle does the psalmist confess in Psalms 77:3?
options: He was troubled and his spirit overwhelmed
questions.correctAnswer: He was troubled and his spirit overwhelmed
questions.explanation: Psalms 77:3 states, 'I remembered God, and was troubled: I complained, and my spirit was overwhelmed.' This reveals a struggle of faith and emotional turmoil, paralleling themes in Psalm 73:21, Jeremiah 20:14, Habakkuk 3:17-18, and Hebrews 12:3.

questions.question: According to Psalms 77, what does the psalmist do to seek reassurance about God’s faithfulness?
options: He remembers the works and wonders of the LORD
He ignores past experiences and focuses on present pain
questions.correctAnswer: He remembers the works and wonders of the LORD
questions.explanation: Psalms 77:11-12 says, 'I will remember the works of the LORD... and talk of thy doings,' showing that recalling God's past faithfulness is key to reassurance. This is consistent with Deuteronomy 32:7, Psalm 105:5, Isaiah 63:7, and 1 Corinthians 10:11.

questions.question: What question does the psalmist ask about God's mercy and promises in Psalms 77?
options: Will the Lord cast off forever and be favorable no more?
Has God given new promises to the nations?
Will God bless only the Gentiles?
Is God's mercy unlimited and unconditional?
questions.correctAnswer: Will the Lord cast off forever and be favorable no more?
questions.explanation: Psalms 77:7-8 asks if God will reject and cease to be merciful, reflecting doubt about divine faithfulness. This question is echoed in Lamentations 3:31, Psalm 89:33, Hebrews 10:23, and 2 Timothy 2:13 which affirm God's steadfast mercy despite human despair.

questions.question: How does the psalmist describe God's way in Psalms 77:13?
options: God's way is in the sanctuary
God's way is hidden and unknown
God's way is harsh and unforgiving
God's way is dictated by human wisdom
questions.correctAnswer: God's way is in the sanctuary
questions.explanation: Psalms 77:13 says, 'Thy way, O God, is in the sanctuary,' indicating God's holiness and presence among His people. This aligns with Exodus 25:8, Psalm 99:9, Isaiah 57:15, and John 4:24 emphasizing God's dwelling in holiness and worship.

questions.question: What attribute of God is highlighted by the psalmist in Psalms 77:14?
options: God is a doer of wonders who declares strength among the people
God is indifferent to human affairs
questions.correctAnswer: God is a doer of wonders who declares strength among the people
questions.explanation: Psalms 77:14 states, 'Thou art the God that doest wonders: thou hast declared thy strength among the people,' emphasizing God's mighty acts and revelation of power. This matches Exodus 15:11, Isaiah 25:1, Romans 15:18, and Hebrews 2:4 where God's wondrous works authenticate His divine nature.

questions.question: According to Psalms 77:15, how has God demonstrated his redemptive power?
options: By redeeming the sons of Jacob and Joseph with His arm
By abandoning His people in exile
By allowing them to be conquered
questions.correctAnswer: By redeeming the sons of Jacob and Joseph with His arm
questions.explanation: Psalms 77:15 states, 'Thou hast with thine arm redeemed thy people,' showing God's powerful deliverance. This redemption theme is central in Exodus 6:6, Isaiah 63:12, Luke 1:68, and Ephesians 1:7 where God's saving arm rescues His covenant people.

questions.question: What natural phenomena does the psalmist use in Psalms 77 to illustrate God's power?
options: Waters afraid, clouds pouring rain, thunder, and lightnings
Stars falling and moon darkening only
questions.correctAnswer: Waters afraid, clouds pouring rain, thunder, and lightnings
questions.explanation: Verses 16-18 describe waters being afraid, clouds pouring water, thunder, and lightning as displays of God's power. Similar imagery is found in Psalm 29:3-9, Job 38:25-30, Nahum 1:3, and Revelation 8:5 where natural forces manifest God's sovereign strength.

questions.question: In Psalms 77:19, what is said about God's way and path?
options: God's way is in the sea and His path in the great waters, and His footsteps are not known
God's way is easily traced and always visible
God's path is confined to the mountains
God's footsteps are marked by destruction only
questions.correctAnswer: God's way is in the sea and His path in the great waters, and His footsteps are not known
questions.explanation: Psalms 77:19 poetically describes God's mysterious guidance through the sea, symbolizing His sovereign and inscrutable acts. This corresponds with Exodus 14:21-22, Isaiah 43:16, Jonah 2:3, and Hebrews 11:29 where God's path through the waters signifies salvation and divine mystery.

questions.question: Who does the psalmist say God led like a flock in Psalms 77:20?
options: His people by the hand of Moses and Aaron
questions.correctAnswer: His people by the hand of Moses and Aaron
questions.explanation: Psalms 77:20 states, 'Thou leddest thy people like a flock by the hand of Moses and Aaron,' highlighting God’s providential leadership through appointed mediators. This is consistent with Exodus 3:10-12, Numbers 12:7-8, Hebrews 3:1-6, and Acts 7:20-38 where Moses and Aaron lead God's covenant people.

questions.question: What does the psalmist identify as his infirmity in Psalms 77:10?
options: His lack of understanding of the law
questions.correctAnswer: His forgetting God's past faithfulness
questions.explanation: Psalms 77:10 says, 'This is my infirmity,' referring to his doubt and forgetfulness about God's mercy, though he resolves to remember God's mighty works. This struggle of faith is reflected in Psalm 73:21, Jeremiah 3:22, Mark 9:24, and James 1:6-8 emphasizing the human weakness in trust.

questions.question: How does the psalmist describe his self-communion in the night in Psalms 77:6?
options: He communes with his own heart and his spirit makes diligent search
He dismisses his troubles and focuses on sleep
questions.correctAnswer: He communes with his own heart and his spirit makes diligent search
questions.explanation: Psalms 77:6 describes a deep inward reflection during the night, indicating spiritual self-examination. This resonates with Psalm 4:4, Lamentations 3:28, Psalm 63:6, and 1 Corinthians 11:28 where introspection is part of faith seeking understanding.

questions.question: What does the psalmist express about his ability to speak due to his trouble in Psalms 77:4?
options: He is so troubled that he cannot speak
He laughs and mocks his enemies
questions.correctAnswer: He is so troubled that he cannot speak
questions.explanation: Psalms 77:4 states, 'I am so troubled that I cannot speak,' revealing the overwhelming nature of his distress. Similar expressions are found in Job 10:18, Psalm 39:2, Lamentations 2:11, and Romans 7:24 where speechlessness indicates deep anguish.

questions.question: What theological theme is prominent in Psalms 77 through the psalmist’s reflections and questions?
options: The tension between divine hiddenness and faith in God's past acts
The futility of prayer in times of trouble
questions.correctAnswer: The tension between divine hiddenness and faith in God's past acts
questions.explanation: Throughout Psalms 77, the psalmist wrestles with God's apparent silence but resolves by recalling God's powerful works and promises. This tension is a key biblical theme found in Habakkuk 1:2-4, Psalm 13:1-6, John 11:35-44, and 2 Corinthians 5:7 highlighting faith amid doubt.
